name: BeanstalkCreateApplicationVersion
description: Create an application revision for deployment to an environment.
author: Amazon Web Services
helpMarkDown:
Please refer to [AWS Elastic Beanstalk User Guide](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/elasticbeanstalk/latest/dg/Welcome.html) for more details on deploying applications with AWS Elastic Beanstalk.

More information on this task can be found in the [task reference](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/vsts/latest/userguide/elastic-beanstalk-createversion.html).

####Task Permissions
This task requires permissions to call the following AWS service APIs (depending on selected task options, not all APIs may be used):
* elasticbeanstalk:CreateApplicationVersion
* elasticbeanstalk:CreateStorageLocation
* elasticbeanstalk:DescribeApplications
* elasticbeanstalk:DescribeEnvironments

The task also requires permissions to upload your application content to the specified Amazon S3 bucket. Depending on the size of the application bundle, either PutObject or the S3 multi-part upload APIs may be used.

inputs.name: awsCredentials
inputs.label: AWS Credentials
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specifies the AWS credentials to be used by the task in the build agent environment.

You can specify credentials using a service endpoint (of type _AWS_) in the task configuration or you can leave unspecified. If unspecified the task will attempt to obtain credentials from the following sources in order:

* From task variables named _AWS.AccessKeyID_, _AWS.SecretAccessKey_ and optionally _AWS.SessionToken_.
* From credentials set in environment variables in the build agent process. When using environment variables in the build agent process you may use the standard AWS environment variables: _AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID_, _AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY_ and optionally _AWS_SESSION_TOKEN_.
* If the build agent is running on an Amazon EC2 instance, from the instance metadata associated with the EC2 instance. For credentials to be available from EC2 instance metadata the instance must have been started with an instance profile referencing a role granting permissions to the task to make calls to AWS on your behalf. See [Using an IAM Role to Grant Permissions to Applications Running on Amazon EC2 Instances](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_roles_use_switch-role-ec2.html) for more information.

inputs.name: regionName
inputs.label: AWS Region
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The AWS region code (us-east-1, us-west-2 etc) of the region containing the AWS resource(s) the task will use or create. For more information see [AWS Regions and Endpoints](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/rande.html).

If a region is not explicitly configured the task will attempt to obtain the region to be used from the following sources:

* From a task variable named _AWS.Region_.
* From the standard AWS environment variable _AWS_REGION_ in the build agent's environment.
*  If the build agent is running on an Amazon EC2 instance, from instance metadata associated with the EC2 instance.

__Note:__ The regions listed in the picker are those known at the time this software was released. New regions that are not listed may still be used by entering the _region code_ of the region (for example _us_west_2_).

inputs.name: applicationName
inputs.label: Application Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the Elastic Beanstalk application.

inputs.name: applicationType
inputs.label: Deployment Bundle Type
inputs.helpMarkDown: The type of artifact bundle to use for the new application version.

options.aspnet: ASP.NET using a Web Deploy (msdeploy) archive file
options.aspnetCoreWindows: ASP.NET Core using 'dotnet publish' for Windows
options.aspnetCoreLinux: ASP.NET Core using 'dotnet publish' for Linux
options.s3: Pre-existing application bundle in Amazon S3

inputs.name: webDeploymentArchive
inputs.label: Web Deploy Archive
inputs.helpMarkDown: The path to the Web Deploy (msdeploy) archive that contains the application that will be deployed to Elastic Beanstalk. Required if *Deployment Bundle Type* is set to _ASP.NET_.

inputs.name: dotnetPublishPath
inputs.label: Published Application Path
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The output location where the _dotnet publish_ command in your previous build steps placed the deployment artifact(s) to be published. Configure using either:

* The path to the output folder containing the artifacts. Use this if the _dotnet publish_ command in your build was configured to not create a zip file of the published application.
* The path and filename of the zip file containing the artifacts. Use this if the _dotnet publish_ command in your build was configured to create a zip file of the application artifacts.

Required if *Deployment Bundle Type* is set to _ASP.NET Core_.

inputs.name: deploymentBundleBucket
inputs.label: Deployment Bundle Bucket
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the bucket containing the previously uploaded application version bundle. Required if *Deployment Bundle Type* is set to _Pre-existing application bundle in Amazon S3_.

inputs.name: deploymentBundleKey
inputs.label: Deployment Bundle Object Key
inputs.helpMarkDown: The Amazon S3 object key of the version bundle to be registered with Elastic Beanstalk. Required if *Deployment Bundle Type* is set to _Pre-existing application bundle in Amazon S3_.

inputs.name: versionLabel
inputs.label: Version Label
inputs.helpMarkDown: Version label for the new revision. If not specified the task will construct a version label based on the current date and time expressed in milliseconds (for example *v20171120222623*).

inputs.name: outputVariable
inputs.label: Version Label Output Variable
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the variable that will contain the version label of the new application revision.

inputs.name: logRequest
inputs.label: Log Request
inputs.helpMarkDown: If selected, request headers and other data for calls to AWS services are logged to the task's debug log.

inputs.name: logResponse
inputs.label: Log Response
inputs.helpMarkDown: If selected, the response metadata and body content of non-streaming responses from calls to AWS services are output to the task's debug log. The unique request ID, which can be useful when contacting AWS for support, is always logged to the task output regardless of this option setting.

messages.DeterminedBucket: Determine S3 bucket %s to store application bundle
messages.UploadingBundle: Uploading application bundle %s to object %s in bucket %s
messages.BundleUploadFailed: Upload of application bundle failed with error: %s
messages.FailedToFindEnvironment: Failed to find environment when waiting for deployment completion
messages.CreatingBeanstalkBundle: Creating Elastic Beanstalk deployment bundle at %s
messages.AddingAspNetCoreBundle: Adding ASP.NET Core web app to beanstalk bundle, %s
messages.AddingFilesFromDotnetPublish: Adding files from dotnet publish output folder.
messages.AddingManifest: Adding Elastic Beanstalk manifest to bundle
messages.SettingOutputVariable: Setting output variable %s with the version label %s
messages.ApplicationExistsQueryError: DescribeApplications: error %s returned querying for existence of application %s
messages.ApplicationExistsQueryErrorTooManyApplic: DescribeApplications: Too many applications were returned while querying for existence of application %s. List of applications returned: %s
messages.TaskCompleted: Creation of new revision completed successfully
